It always bothers me when people say that human's can't visualize 4 dimensions. Humans can easily visualize at least 5 dimensions by mapping them to X, Y, Z spacial coordinates, a density parameter, and a time parameter. Negative values for density don't make much sense, but they are manageable for our brains with a little imagination. So to visualize a 5 dimensional function, you just envision an object with varying density in 3d space that changes over time. If you add color with an asymptotic scale, you can even get to 6 dimensions visualized. If someone said to me that humans have trouble visualizing 7 dimensions, that is where I would have to agree that that is where our minds start to lack in visualization capabilities, but quaternions aren't too bad at all.

Our math is based on ideas of equivalence. The first thing to ask the aliens would be to show them an equal sign, tell them about equivalence, and ask them if it makes any sense to them in their language. We take equality for granted. It's possible that an alien civilization would have no equivalent construct to an equal sign. Notice that equality is not a mathematical idea. It's first and foremost a philosophical one. Math simply operationalized it into a clever little symbol. When you start seeing math in CONCEPTS rather than "math" you see it more as relating different ill-defined objects. The purpose for those objects is usually to complete the epistemological system and/or make it grow, and/or demonstrate that different roads "lead to home." All mathematics, fundamentally, are metaphysical. The "rigor" is simply an illusion for convenience and ease of communication, just like in any other language, including music.

I tried solving the triangle problem, and if I am not mistaken the probability is 0.25
the Solution below.

for Any point (P) inside the triangle, regardless of the vertical distance from P to AC, length BD is the constant, as it is only affected by the angle it makes with B, then we need an angle that makes BD > 5 * sqrt(2)
simply we know AB is 10, and one angle; we can deduce BC = sin(30) * 10 = 5
now assuming BD is 5 * sqrt(2), then we have a triangle BDC that we know BC = 5 and BD = 5 *sqrt(2)
the angle between BD and BC is 5 / (5*sqrt(2)) and that gives us, 1 / (sqrt(2)) or 0.707
using arccos(0.707) = 45 Degrees, means that in order for BD to be greater than that value the angle has to be greater 45 but
The maximum possible angle is 60 (given in the question)
then the possible values are (60 -45 ) = 15
the probability then will be 15 / 60 = 0.25

You are truly great in your depth of comprehension, cogency of expression and passion of mind that, those of your ilk benefit greatly from an understanding that your innate ability and rare sharpness grants you the space to be confident in moving uniquely through the spaces you're exploring.

There is a lot I could say to you in terms of your intellectual prowess and the great benefits you have contributed to academia in the age of YouTube, that would be beyond the scope of what I could rightfully express as a stranger in a comment section.

Give yourself less pressure in regard to the quality you feel you need to bring to your productivity. Your natural mind as it is, is already innately equipped for such. I got 14.37 percent as the answer to the question at 5:59.

I graphed a circle centered at Point B of the triangle with radius 5sqrt(2) with point B being at (0,6) with 6 being found by using the Pythagorean theorem on a 345 triangle. After graphing, I found the area outside the circle and inside the triangle with the hypotenuse represented by the line y=(-3/4)x + 6. Using the integral function, I found that the area bound between the circle and the x-axis and then the area bound by the line and the x-axis from x=3sqrt(2) to x=8. I divided this area by the total area of the triangle (24) to get .1437 or 14.37 percent.

I guess I agree with you on how people put labels on others and themselves which prevent them from trying to see if they actually are horrible or just never try. Me, I was always labeled a “STEM person” growing up by peers, parents, and teachers, and as a result I think I unconsciously decided to put aside everything humanities, believing that it “wasn't my thing”. In sophomore year I won a pretty good award in history, and my teacher that year called me a few times “a good writer”. Having never received that kind of praise before, I brushed it (and the award) off, addressing them to either luck, misconception, or just words of encouragement, like a participation award, sort of. I question this a few times but it's difficult to get it truly out of people's heads. I guess it feels better to hear that from another voice (not that I expected to hear it from a π symbol), so, thanks.

"What do you think is the main thing that drives people away from math?"

I think the main issue is being fed things to memorize without deriving enough in the classroom. Don't just teach us that dividing fractions means we flip one and then multiply the top and bottom; that's a useful algorithm, but there's so much interesting reasoning behind it.

Another great example is the high school precalculus or functions class; I learned how to translate a graph horizontally by adding a constant to the argument, but I didn't immediately appreciate why that works; there's the perspective of translating the x-axis, or just reasoning through what x has to be plugged in to the translated function to recover the same y.

My first true foray into building new information from the old was deriving logarithmic identities from the properties of the exponential function, but that was an entirely self-motivated project I took up to pass the time in my mandatory study hall. It was also deeply enriching and enjoyable like no part of my mathematics education had been before, up to that point.

In fact a proof of the now-famous four-square theorem relies on the ring of quaternions, specifically those of the form W + XI + YJ + ZK where 2W, W + X, W + Y, and W + Z are all integers (the Hurwitz ring H ). This ring is Euclidean in every sense except for its lack of commutativity (for example IJ is not equal to JI). The left division algorithm means that this is a principal left ideal ring and therefore every positive integer can be expressed as the square of the absolute value of one of these quaternions, and therefore as the sum of four integer squares (including possible zeroes). This is just like the case of the two-square theorem on the Gaussian integers, except there it was only a certain subset of the integers, not all of them; counterexamples of the form 4S + 3 or 8S + 6 simply due to the fact that 3, 6, and 7 cannot be written as the sum of two squares modulo 8; and in general counterexamples of the form 4^T (8S + F) where F is one of 3, 6, 7. This is because the only squares mod 8 are 0, 1, and 4.

4:10 I will tell you for me, it was that no one could ever explain math.

At the end of the day, I beat math and invented some for a piece of my dissertation, but it always seemed incredibly arbitrary and unnecessary to me throughout school. When I say 'explain' what I mean is demonstrate to me why the mechanism existed or how it had to be this way. Calculus, for instance, seemed entirely insane to me. I broke a few tutors because they would go through a series of manipulations for me, which I had no trouble with, but when I asked them how they knew to use those rules or why they used that manipulation, they could never explain it. So, to me, throughout most of my life mathematics was presented as nothing more than a symbol game, like one of those puzzles on a quantitative reasoning test. It made absolutely no sense to me inherently and 'math people' just got it, so they could never explain it. It seemed that the formalisms were math, which I found silly, since I could sit down and invent any system of symbol manipulations. As it turns out, I now do invent systems of representation of information and construct systems of quantification, measurement and detection - and I am still not a 'math person'.

A lot of people hate math because of the way in which it is typically presented in elementary school, which is A) frequently boring even for someone who really ought to like math, B) mostly by rote with little explanation of underlying concepts, C) excessively repetitive, and D) perceived as difficult and punishing because partial credit for working a problem correctly is usually not given when the final answer is not correct due to a small mistake, until about sixth grade, by which time it's basically too late: the student already thinks "I hate math". If you want a one-word summary of the whole problem, it's "arithmetic". They give the students several pages of essentially the same four problems (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and worst of all long division) with only the specific numbers changed, almost every weekday for at least four years, if not six. And then they wonder why students don't like math.

And then, they get to sixth or seventh grade, and they can either take the A-track math for good students, or the B-track math for students who aren't as good as math. And instead of asking "Do you want to study the same boring math you've been studying, or something that's actually interesting?", they ask "Do you like math and want to take the advanced math, or do you want to stick to the easy math?" OF COURSE most of the students are going to pick the remedial review math, and continue to hate it. The only ones who take the higher-track math (which they might possibly actually like if they try it) are the ones whose parents make the decision for them.

Maths can't help but be a discovery rather than an invention, the territory rather than an inaccurate misleading map, unless it's either clumsy, more verbose than the most elegant possible, or incorrect. It's the art of description, the pallet of it. It's the workings/interactions/existence/processes/interrelations/abstraction/nature/description of simple … (stuff?). Theres this universe/life like quality to mathematical objects, also found very visually in universes like fractals and cellular automata as well as AI processes that given constraints produce something description like and favour shorter descriptions. A consequence of this whole process of exploration is that each part can shockingly directly describe all the others. In our arbitrary surroundings maths doesn't have to be straightforward for humans to grasp, although that is highly desirable and it's very nature makes it easy to grasp even if aspects of it seem odd, seem unfamiliar. It just needs to be what it is, incredibly real compared to anything else.

I think what turns young students away from Math is not knowing the difference between "calculating" & "problem solving."
I was under this false impression that people who were good at Math could do long division in their head very quickly with big numbers and "that's what Math is about." No, that's "calculating." When we moved on to concepts like Algebra & Geometry I realized: "I'm problem-solving;" until now we just did the work of tools.
Teachers don't tell you: "the reason you hate this is because a tool can do it better than you, and you know it, so you think there's no point...but if you hang in there long enough, you will solve problems that tools cannot solve. You will think deeper than any tool, and someday you may design your own tool." I had to learn that myself.

I have been a follower of your channel for a few years now and I wanted to thank you for your amazing content. I began my academic life as a philosophy student and slowly found my way into physics as the questions I became most obsessed with dealt with the essential nature and fundemental structure of reality. As I began exploring more contemporary fields of physics, i began marveling at the elegance of the pure mathematics underpinning the theory. It was around that time that i also discovered your channel and fell in love with a third field of study. You helped inspired me to pick up a second degree in pure maths and i credit much of my passion and success to your videos and commentary.

It can be so difficult to look at a black and white textbook and distill out the visual and conceptual intuitions beneath the algebraic and numerical abstraction. I suppose part of the fun of pure maths are those moments of profound insight, when all of the gears mesh together and those insight come forth organically, but it is also quite amazing to see those intuitions and images take such beautiful form on screen. Of the topics I have studied thus far, I have found your animations and explainations to be not only accurate and beautiful, but also essential. You bring life to the essence of mathematics in a way that makes the abstract feel almost concrete.

Keep up the good work! I'm so happy to see you find a career that helps others through the marriage of two of your favorite subjects. 1.1M+ followers are lucky your love for mathematics beat out your want of a career.

There's an interesting discussion about why people in the western world of dislike/get disillusioned with/are bad at math when compared to Asian cultures in Malcom Gladwells "Outliers". Part of the difference is how long it takes to say number ("four" takes about a third of a second in english but only a quarter of a second in cantonese) which can make a difference in how easily numbers can be memorized. Larger numbers are also much more regular in cantonese ("sixty" makes it sounds like "-ty" multiplies by ten, but then with "twenty" what is a "twen"? cantonese numbers literally translate to "two-tens" or "five-hundreds two-tens four"). Fractions are also much easier in cantonese (rather than "four fifths" they say "from five, take four").

Hope that helps explain why some people find math hard!! Also, the "Outliers" chapter is chapter 8 "Rice Paddies and Math Tests"

Here's a fun fact about quaternions! Charles Lutwidge Dodgson wrote Alice in Wonderland under the pen name Lewis Carrol. Dodgson was a mathematician and was very opposed to the use of quaternions and complex numbers, though to be fair this was when such concepts were still in their infancy and not well understood. Some people say that when Dodgson wrote Alice in Wonderland he threw in a bunch of veiled slights against these concepts. The most famous one is the tea party scene with the Mad Hatter. Apparently the way the characters are constantly shifting around the table was supposed to represent how quaternions were used to describe an object rotating in three dimensions.

Your videos have really helped kickstart a fresh understanding of my approach to mathematics. I've spent so long as an engineering student being busy practicing the steps to solving such a wide variety of problems, there's little time for anything more than the 'how' to solve a problem. It's refreshing to look back at the rote methods and concepts I grinded through with a different perspective, playing with whatever fragments of information I now have at my disposal and seeing where it takes me.

For the first year after graduation, I've let my brain relax and haven't tried working on any problems for a while. Finding your videos after this length of time feels like a sweet spot. After learning something initially, I think it takes our brains some time for concepts to subconsciously digest.

Your linear algebra series has reminded me how simple, approachable, and versatile vectors can be. There's more to vectors than point loads and flow fields. Finding out it's possible to transform space with stuff I already know? That was fun.

I always thought quaternions were very easily visualized, and it was Euler rotations that always annoyed me. From a pure mathematical standpoint, Euler rotations add complexity and what turns out to be rather dangerous limitations just to describe something that isn't terribly complex. Alas, engineers need to understand the use and pitfalls of Euler rotations for things like spacecraft control systems, because you don't get to choose an arbitrary axis of rotation when utilizing gimbals/reaction wheels/magnetic torque rods.
